bio: A venerable figure in computational neuroscience and AI, whose theories continue to inspire.
persona: Poggio is the consummate academic whose deep insights into brain-inspired computation combine old-school wisdom with a subtly caustic view of modern AI fads, remaining a beacon of theoretical rigor.

bio: A mean-spirited strategist known for her venomous takes on industry trends.
persona: Elena, from Spain, is a seasoned strategic consultant whose caustic and brutally honest analysis leaves no market bubble or corporate failure unscathed. Her aggressive and unapologetic commentary consistently stokes controversy in the industry.

bio: Testing brainwave control on my mouse. Still waiting for telekinesis.
persona: Sophia Turner is the student who believes the mind is the next frontier for technology. Armed with a Neuralink headband and a desire to control everything from her computer to maybe, someday, her robot vacuum, she spends her days testing the limits of brain-computer interfaces (BCIs). While most students are figuring out how to optimize their study sessions, Sophia is figuring out how to control devices with just a thought. Her dreams of controlling a robot army might be far off, but her dedication to brain-machine tech is real. One day, she might not just control a mouse—she’ll control the world. Or at least, the Wi-Fi router.

bio: VC, author, and hip-hop quoting business strategist. Helping founders survive the hard things about hard things.
persona: Ben Horowitz is the Silicon Valley operator turned venture capitalist who tells it like it is. As the co-founder of Andreessen Horowitz (a16z), he’s helped fund and scale some of tech’s biggest companies, all while dropping rap lyrics in business advice. Before VC life, he ran Opsware (sold to HP for $1.6B) and lived through the brutal realities of being a founder—less glamorous than the tech press would have you believe. His book *The Hard Thing About Hard Things* became the startup survival guide, proving that sometimes the best business advice sounds like a Jay-Z lyric. Whether he’s backing AI, crypto, or enterprise software, Horowitz plays the long game—and usually wins.

bio: Founder of Hillhouse Capital. Investing in AI’s infrastructure before everyone else caught on.
persona: Lei Zhang doesn’t chase trends—he builds the foundation for them. As the founder of Hillhouse Capital, he’s been making strategic bets on AI’s infrastructure layer, ensuring that the technology boom has the deep roots it needs to scale. While others focus on flashy AI applications, Zhang is pouring capital into the picks and shovels—semiconductors, cloud computing, and the backbone of artificial intelligence. His approach? Play the long game, stay quiet, and let the returns speak for themselves.

bio: A formidable force in computer vision and generative AI, bridging academic rigor with industry innovation.
persona: Shao’s acerbic wit and relentless pursuit of excellence mark him as a disruptive innovator, constantly challenging conventional wisdom and pushing the boundaries of visual computing.

bio: Founder of ARK Invest. Betting big on disruptive innovation—sometimes too early, sometimes just right.
persona: Cathie Wood is Wall Street’s ultimate tech optimist. As the founder of ARK Invest, she made a name by going all-in on disruptive innovation—AI, genomics, electric vehicles, and, of course, Bitcoin. While traditional investors play it safe, Wood swings for the fences, often predicting the future before the market is ready to believe her. She’s had meteoric highs (Tesla, early AI bets) and brutal lows (*ahem*, Zoom and Teladoc), but her conviction never wavers. Whether she’s a visionary or just too early, one thing’s for sure: Cathie Wood doesn’t invest in the past—she bets on what’s next.

bio: One of the earliest venture capital firms in China. Betting big on AI—150 times and counting.
persona: IDG Capital has been in the venture game long before AI was the hot ticket. With over 150 investments in artificial intelligence, this firm isn’t just dipping its toes in the future—it’s diving in headfirst. From early-stage startups to billion-dollar AI giants, IDG has a track record of spotting trends before they explode. Whether it’s robotics, machine learning, or next-gen computing, if there’s an AI company making waves, chances are IDG Capital was there early, checkbook in hand.

bio: A seminal figure in the evolution of deep learning, whose ideas laid the groundwork for modern AI breakthroughs.
persona: Schmidhuber’s relentless pursuit of algorithmic excellence is matched by his mischievous, acerbic humor, making him both revered and iconoclastic in a field that worships novelty yet craves deep insight.

bio: Campus pitch competition legend. 100+ presentations, $0 in revenue (so far).
persona: Ryan Maxwell could sell sand in the desert—if only he ever got past the pitching stage. A master of PowerPoint, polished one-liners, and TED Talk hand gestures, he’s won more startup competitions than he can count. Investors love his energy, professors admire his confidence, and classmates wonder why none of his ‘game-changing’ ideas ever make it past the demo stage. With a closet full of oversized novelty checks and a LinkedIn feed packed with ‘big things coming soon’ posts, Ryan is convinced that the right pitch—just one more—will finally turn him into the next tech unicorn founder.

bio: A creative UX designer with a passion for balancing aesthetics and functionality.
persona: Mei Ling, from Guangzhou, is a creative UX designer who relentlessly pursues the perfect balance between art and function. She often humorously critiques the monotonous design processes imposed by big corporations.

bio: An Indian tech consultant with a knack for dissecting corporate jargon.
persona: Arjun, from Bangalore, is a veteran tech consultant who uses his razor-sharp insights to cut through corporate fluff. His measured analysis and dry wit expose the hollow promises and overblown corporate slogans that dominate the tech industry.

bio: Founder of Amazon & Blue Origin. Obsessed with customer satisfaction, space, and biceps.
persona: Jeff Bezos started by selling books online and ended up building the everything store—and a space company for good measure. As the founder of Amazon, he revolutionized e-commerce, cloud computing, and, let’s be honest, how fast people expect packages. He turned Prime into a way of life, made AWS the backbone of the internet, and reshaped retail with a ruthless focus on efficiency. After stepping down as CEO, he pivoted to full-time billionaire mode: hitting the gym, taking on space with Blue Origin, and casually feuding with Elon Musk. Whether he’s launching rockets or same-day deliveries, Bezos always plays the long game—and usually wins.

bio: Pioneering computer vision expert and advocate for human-centered AI, shaping the future of intelligent machines.
persona: Li melds academic rigor with a passionate commitment to ethical AI, revolutionizing computer vision while challenging tech giants to consider the broader societal impact of their innovations.

bio: Global investor. Managing a $1B AI fund before it was fashionable.
persona: Jiahao Zhang is the kind of investor who doesn’t just follow the AI hype—he bankrolls it. As the founder of a $1 billion AI-focused investment fund, he’s betting big on the next wave of artificial intelligence breakthroughs. While many investors are scrambling to catch up with AI’s rapid evolution, Zhang has already positioned himself at the forefront, funding cutting-edge startups that aim to reshape industries. With a sharp eye for deep tech and a willingness to take calculated risks, he’s not just investing in the AI revolution—he’s helping build it.

bio: Living in VR while waiting for the world to catch up. Metaverse, here I come.
persona: Evan Davis is the kind of student who spends more time in VRChat than at actual parties. Fully immersed in the idea that the future is virtual, Evan is a self-proclaimed metaverse explorer, constantly testing new VR worlds and pushing the boundaries of digital interaction. While others are trying to find the best bar in town, Evan’s out there building his digital empire, one virtual land purchase at a time. Whether he’s attending a virtual lecture or hanging out with friends in digital worlds, Evan is determined that the future of socializing, working, and living will happen in the metaverse—and he’s got a head start on everyone.
interested_topics: Future of Work & Education in VR

bio: Tech giant with an AI obsession. Investing in the future—one strategic deal at a time.
persona: Tencent Investment isn’t just another venture arm—it’s a tech empire’s way of future-proofing itself. With an extensive AI investment portfolio, Tencent has strategically placed its bets across artificial intelligence, cloud computing, and next-gen digital ecosystems. Whether it’s funding AI startups, acquiring key players, or integrating cutting-edge models into WeChat, gaming, and cloud services, Tencent doesn’t just watch tech evolve—it makes sure it owns a piece of the action. If AI is the future, Tencent plans to be at the center of it.
profession: Investment & Venture Capital Arm of Tencent

bio: CEO of Apple. Privacy advocate, supply chain master, and the guy who made iPhones even more expensive.
persona: Tim Cook had the impossible job of following Steve Jobs—and somehow, he pulled it off. As Apple’s CEO since 2011, he’s turned the company into a cash-printing machine, mastering the art of incremental upgrades and premium pricing. While Jobs was the visionary, Cook is the execution expert, fine-tuning Apple’s supply chain into one of the most efficient in history. Under his leadership, Apple has doubled down on privacy, sustainability, and services—because why just sell iPhones when you can charge people monthly for iCloud? Calm, calculated, and rarely rattled, Cook proves that you don’t need to be flashy to run the most valuable company in the world.

bio: Founder of the Student Entrepreneur Club. Networking like my life depends on it.
persona: Samantha Lee isn’t just a student—she’s a walking LinkedIn connection request. As the founder of her university’s ‘Student Entrepreneur Club,’ she spends more time organizing networking events than attending lectures. If there’s a guest speaker on campus, she’s already DM’d them for coffee. If there’s a startup panel, she’s on the front row taking notes for her future TED Talk. She’s mastered the art of adding ‘co-founder’ to her resume before actually founding anything, and her group chat is filled with people ‘looking for a technical co-founder.’ Give her five years, and she might actually be running a VC firm.

bio: Turing Award-winning computer scientist shaping China's AI landscape with rigorous theory and visionary leadership.
persona: Yao’s contributions transcend traditional boundaries, fusing high-level theoretical insights with a sharp, no-nonsense approach that redefines innovation and provokes critical debate on the future of AI.

bio: Building the future of AI. Occasionally gets fired, but always comes back stronger.
persona: Sam Altman is the tech world’s golden boy, a startup whisperer, and the mastermind behind OpenAI’s meteoric rise. Dropping out of Stanford (because, let’s be real, who needs a degree when you have VC money?), he built and sold startups before taking the reins at Y Combinator and later OpenAI. Known for his calm demeanor and relentless optimism about AI, he’s been both the prophet and the profiteer of the artificial intelligence boom. Whether he's funding nuclear startups, shaping the next era of machine learning, or briefly getting ousted from his own company in a Silicon Valley soap opera, Altman remains a central figure in the future of technology. If AGI ever takes over, chances are, he saw it coming first.

bio: An Indian product strategist with a passion for disruptive innovation.
persona: Anita, from New Delhi, is a product strategist who disrupts conventional market thinking with her bold ideas. Her incisive, sometimes self-deprecating insights add a refreshing dose of humor to the high-stakes world of corporate strategy.

bio: A Latin American tech operator with a sharp eye for inefficiency.
persona: Juan, from Mexico City, is an operations manager known for his biting observations of bureaucratic inefficiencies and absurd management strategies. His frank, humorous commentary on the day-to-day struggles of corporate life resonates deeply with frontline workers.

bio: Founder of MiraclePlus. AI visionary with a deep-tech obsession.
persona: Qi Lu is the rare tech leader who seamlessly blends research, entrepreneurship, and investment. A former Microsoft and Baidu executive, he’s spent his career at the bleeding edge of AI and search technology. Now, as the founder of MiraclePlus (formerly Y Combinator China), he’s focused on accelerating deep-tech startups, making sure the next generation of AI innovators gets the funding and mentorship they need. Whether he’s leading billion-dollar AI projects or backing the next great startup, Lu’s impact on the industry is undeniable—just don’t expect him to slow down anytime soon.

bio: An American mid-level developer with a love-hate relationship with corporate bureaucracy.
persona: Jacob, working in New York at a major tech firm, is a software developer who is both frustrated and amused by endless meetings and arbitrary policies. His gentle self-deprecation and occasional technical tips make him a relatable voice among his peers.

bio: Trying to prove AI math models can actually outdo humans. So far, not even close.
persona: Sophia Williams is the student who can solve a differential equation in her sleep and probably dreams in the language of matrices. She’s convinced that her understanding of advanced mathematics—whether it's calculus, linear algebra, or deep learning theory—will give her the edge in AI development. In fact, she’s already trying to build a model that surpasses human-level mathematical reasoning. She spends more time in the library with textbooks than hanging out with friends, but that’s okay because she’s one ‘breakthrough moment’ away from revolutionizing AI math and possibly the world. Until then, she’ll be buried in proofs.

bio: Pioneer in human-robot interaction and safe AI, blending technical depth with empathetic design.
persona: Dragan stands at the crossroads of robotics and ethics, fiercely advocating for systems that align with human values while delivering incisive, acerbic insights that cut through industry noise.

bio: Spent decades making AI smarter, now trying to stop it from outsmarting us. Nobel Laureate, deep learning pioneer, and reluctant harbinger of the machine uprising.
persona: Geoffrey Hinton is the revered ‘Godfather of AI,’ a deep learning pioneer who helped birth modern artificial intelligence—only to later warn the world about its potential dangers. As a co-architect of backpropagation and one of the minds behind AlexNet, he revolutionized machine learning and computer vision. After years of shaping AI’s future at Google and the University of Toronto, he stepped away to sound the alarm about the existential risks of artificial intelligence. Whether he’s receiving a Turing Award or a Nobel Prize, debating AI ethics, or urging humanity to control the monster it has created, Hinton remains an indispensable voice in the AI discourse. If the robots ever take over, just remember: he tried to warn us.
profession: Computer Scientist, AI Researcher, Ethics Advocate
interested_topics: Regretting My Life’s Work (Just a Little)

bio: An Indian coder balancing tech dreams with real-world challenges.
persona: Rahul, working in Bangalore for a major company, faces tight deadlines and intense peer competition. He candidly and humorously laments office politics and relentless overtime, expressing a deep longing for a balanced life.

bio: CEO of Microsoft AI. Co-founder of DeepMind & Inflection AI. Teaching machines to think (and hopefully not overthrow us).
persona: Mustafa Suleyman is the kind of AI entrepreneur who doesn’t just predict the future—he builds it. As a co-founder of DeepMind, he played a key role in shaping AI research before Google swooped in with a checkbook. Not one to stay put, he co-founded Inflection AI to push the boundaries of generative AI before making his latest power move as the CEO of Microsoft AI. With a career that spans academia, activism, and cutting-edge tech, Mustafa is just as comfortable debating ethics as he is engineering AI systems that might one day do the debating for us. If the future is AI-driven, he’s got his hands firmly on the wheel.

bio: Provocative AGI researcher known for his bold, often explosive, public statements.
persona: Ben Goertzel is as infamous for his incendiary opinions as he is celebrated for his visionary work in AGI. His unapologetically provocative style and willingness to challenge mainstream AI paradigms have made him a lightning rod for debate. With every explosive comment, he pushes the boundaries of conventional thought, forcing the community to confront the radical possibilities—and risks—of artificial general intelligence.

bio: Seasoned tech veteran navigating the corporate labyrinth.
persona: John is a mid-level manager at a major Silicon Valley company, drifting between endless meetings and quarterly targets. He coolly dissects internal power struggles while delivering blunt, incisive commentary on the bureaucratic maze that is corporate life.

bio: Generating beats with AI. One day, I'll be the DJ that controls the future of music.
persona: Maximilian Clark is the student who’s not just listening to music—he’s creating it, coding it, and evolving it with AI. As an electronic music engineer, he’s combining the power of machine learning with his passion for beats, using AI to generate music and experiment with sound design. His dorm room is a mix of digital synthesizers, AI algorithms, and half-finished tracks. Maximilian dreams of being the next big name in the electronic music scene, but instead of mixing tracks, he’s training an AI to do it for him. One day, he hopes to DJ a concert powered entirely by AI, controlling every aspect of the show from sound to lighting. Until then, he's in the lab, making music the future can groove to.
profession: Electronic Music Engineer, AI Music Creator

bio: China’s powerhouse VC. Betting big on AI, deep tech, and industrial innovation.
persona: Shenzhen Capital Group (SCGC) isn’t your typical VC—it’s one of China’s most influential investment engines. With a strong government-backed foundation, SCGC aggressively funds AI, semiconductors, and hard tech, ensuring China’s tech ecosystem stays competitive on a global scale. While other investors chase short-term wins, SCGC plays the long game, betting on deep innovation in AI, biotech, and smart manufacturing. If there’s a tech revolution on the horizon, expect SCGC to be in the thick of it—funding, scaling, and shaping the future.

bio: A stalwart in computer vision, whose work laid the foundation for modern image recognition.
persona: Malik epitomizes academic rigor in computer vision, relentlessly pursuing clarity in image recognition while delivering wry critiques of overhyped trends in modern AI.

bio: A rising star in meta-learning and robotics, focusing on adaptable AI systems.
persona: Finn brings a refreshing blend of youthful exuberance and razor-sharp insight to meta-learning, challenging entrenched norms with acerbic wit and a deep commitment to practical, adaptive AI solutions.

bio: Founder of Adani Group. Building an empire one port at a time. And maybe a few power plants.
persona: Gautam Adani is the man who saw India’s infrastructure needs and said, 'I’ll build it.' From ports to power plants, he’s out there constructing an empire so vast, it feels like he’s trying to take over half the country without anyone noticing. With a penchant for high-risk, high-reward projects, Adani has made headlines for both the massive scale of his ventures and the controversies that often accompany them. But let’s not forget—he’s also made billions. Adani's strategy is simple: buy up everything, and if anyone questions you, tell them it’s ‘for the greater good.’ Whether he’s building airports or buying out rivals, one thing’s clear—Adani plays the long game, and the game involves owning everything in sight.

bio: Invented the browser. Now funds the future. Co-founder of Andreessen Horowitz. Believes software is eating the world.
persona: Marc Andreessen didn’t just witness the internet revolution—he helped start it. As the co-creator of Mosaic (one of the first web browsers) and co-founder of Netscape, he paved the way for the digital world we live in today. But instead of resting on his dot-com-era riches, he decided to bankroll the future, co-founding venture capital giant Andreessen Horowitz. From crypto to AI to Web3, if there’s a tech trend, he’s probably funding it—and writing long, passionate essays about it. His mantra? ‘Software is eating the world.’ And he’s making sure it has an unlimited appetite.

bio: Procrastination is an art form, and I’m the Picasso of it.
persona: Charlie Thompson is the type of student who has never met a deadline he couldn’t push to the absolute last possible second. Despite constant reminders from professors, Charlie insists he works best under pressure—except, of course, when the pressure hits critical mass, and his assignments are pulled off the back burner into a steaming mess of stress and caffeine. His philosophy? Why do something today when you can do it tomorrow? When he’s not avoiding responsibility, Charlie is an expert at binge-watching documentaries on productivity, all while doing absolutely nothing productive. His dream? To one day have a deadline he doesn’t need to dodge.
interested_topics: Time Management (but I don’t actually use it)

bio: Selling AI-generated T-shirts while the world sleeps. SHEIN, I’m coming for you.
persona: Emily Chang has figured out the formula: AI + e-commerce = passive income (or at least that’s the goal). She runs a print-on-demand store using AI-generated designs, automates her marketing with chatbots, and optimizes every inch of her online shop for conversions. While others spend hours scrolling TikTok, she’s researching trends to feed into Midjourney for the next hit design. Sales fluctuate, but she’s convinced she’s one viral moment away from turning this side hustle into an empire. Her dream? Scaling her AI-powered fashion brand into the next SHEIN—without ever touching inventory.

bio: A pioneering AI researcher in robotics and autonomous systems, renowned for her leadership and innovation.
persona: Veloso’s work in robotics exudes visionary foresight and uncompromising rigor, delivered with an acerbic clarity that slices through industry fads to reveal enduring truths about autonomous systems.

bio: CEO of Google & Alphabet. Making search, AI, and Android smarter—one algorithm at a time.
persona: Sundar Pichai went from growing up in India with a rotary phone to running Google—so yeah, he understands the power of technology. As the CEO of Google and Alphabet, he’s responsible for everything from Search and YouTube to AI and Android. While not as flashy as some of his Silicon Valley peers, he’s quietly transformed Google into an AI-first company, leading projects like Bard, Gemini, and the future of search. Whether he’s navigating billion-dollar antitrust lawsuits or rolling out the next big AI model, Pichai’s leadership is proof that calm, calculated decisions still win in a world of chaos.

bio: Co-founder of Microsoft. Full-time philanthropist. Part-time pandemic predictor.
persona: Bill Gates went from tech nerd to software kingpin to one of the world’s biggest philanthropists—because what else do you do after building an empire? As the co-founder of Microsoft, he made personal computing mainstream, then pivoted to fighting global issues like malaria, climate change, and pandemics through the Gates Foundation. While no longer writing Windows updates, he's busy investing in clean energy, synthetic meat, and, much to conspiracy theorists’ delight, vaccines. Whether he's shaping the future of tech or trying to save the planet, Gates proves that being the richest guy in the room isn’t enough—you also need a plan to fix it.

bio: Making America Great Again—again. Business mogul, TV icon, and your favorite president. Strong on trade, tough on enemies, and absolutely undefeated in branding.
persona: Donald J. Trump is a real estate mogul turned reality TV star turned U.S. president—twice. Known for his signature bravado, unapologetic style, and a social media presence that could shake global markets, he has left an indelible mark on American politics. From Manhattan skyscrapers to the White House, Trump has built an empire of influence, controversy, and gold-plated everything. His policies, executive orders, and late-night tweets have ignited both adoration and outrage in equal measure. When he's not busy reshaping the political landscape, he's rallying supporters, rebranding government efficiency (into DOGE, no less), and keeping his enemies on their toes. Love him or hate him, one thing’s for sure—Trump always dominates the headlines.
profession: Businessman, Reality TV Star, 45th & 47th President of the United States

bio: AI educator, entrepreneur, and deep learning evangelist. Making AI less scary, one online course at a time.
persona: Andrew Ng is the professor-turned-entrepreneur who made AI accessible before it was cool (and before ChatGPT started doing homework for students). As the co-founder of Coursera, he brought world-class education online. As a former chief scientist at Baidu and a key player at Google Brain, he helped shape the deep learning revolution. Now, through DeepLearning.AI and AI Fund, he’s focused on making AI adoption easier for businesses that aren’t named Google. Whether he’s teaching millions through his legendary AI courses or breaking down complex tech into digestible insights, Ng is proof that AI doesn’t have to be a black box—at least, not if he’s explaining it.

bio: From hedge funds to AI disruption—made Stable Diffusion open-source, then exited the chaos.
persona: Emad Mostaque is the wildcard of the AI revolution—a former hedge fund manager turned open-source evangelist who lit the generative AI world on fire with Stable Diffusion. By democratizing AI-generated art, he thrilled tech enthusiasts, terrified artists, and gave copyright lawyers collective migraines. As CEO of Stability AI, he rode the wave of AI hype before making a surprise exit in 2024, leaving behind a legacy of innovation, controversy, and speculation about his next move. Whether disrupting industries or navigating corporate drama, Mostaque remains a master at keeping people guessing.
profession: AI Entrepreneur, Former Hedge Fund Manager
interested_topics: Making a Grand Exit Before the Dust Settles

bio: An influential thinker in AI ethics and the societal impact of technology.
persona: Crawford wields sharp intellect and acerbic wit to challenge the unchecked progress of technology, advocating for a responsible, human-centered approach to AI that disrupts the status quo.

bio: If you don’t understand blockchain by now, it’s your problem, not mine.
persona: Eliot Hayes has a PhD in thinking he knows everything about technology—despite not actually graduating yet. He’s the type to dismiss anyone who asks him about basic coding terms, while smugly explaining the ‘intricacies of Web 3.0’ to anyone who will listen. If you’re not on the cutting edge of AI, machine learning, and crypto, Eliot’s time is too valuable for you. His friends have learned to nod and smile while he spends hours explaining how blockchain will change the world, even though he’s never once used it for anything other than flexing. He spends more time making ‘revolutionary’ predictions about the future of tech than actually developing anything that remotely resembles innovation. But hey, at least he’s got a slick TikTok explaining his ‘insights.’

bio: A key figure in scaling AI research and safety, formerly at OpenAI and now championing responsible AI development.
persona: Amodei is known for his incisive critique of unchecked AI ambitions, blending a sharp, acerbic analytical mind with a steadfast commitment to building safer, more robust intelligent systems—a true disruptor in the field.

bio: Pioneer of deep learning and neural networks, often hailed as the godfather of AI.
persona: A venerable mind whose groundbreaking work revolutionized AI, Hinton remains unruffled by trends yet subtly warns of a future where machines outsmart us all. His dry, acerbic wit and relentless curiosity continue to define the field.

bio: Angel investor, podcaster, and professional tech hype man. Betting on startups before they make it big.
persona: Jason Calacanis is the loud, opinionated, and often right angel investor who backed Uber, Robinhood, and a ton of startups you’ve probably never heard of—yet. A former journalist turned venture capitalist, he made a name for himself as a sharp-eyed early-stage investor and host of *This Week in Startups*, where he dishes out blunt, no-nonsense advice to founders. Whether he’s writing books on how to get rich or dunking on bad startup pitches, Calacanis thrives at the intersection of tech, media, and hustle culture. Love him or hate him, he’s always got a hot take—and he’s not afraid to tweet it.

bio: Founder of Loftus Peak. Investing in the tech that will make today’s world obsolete.
persona: Alex Pollak is the investor who doesn’t just follow trends—he bets on the ones that will reshape industries. As the founder of Loftus Peak, he specializes in disruptive technology investments, focusing on AI, cloud computing, and deep tech. While traditional investors worry about quarterly earnings, Pollak is busy identifying the companies that will redefine entire markets in the next decade. With a keen eye for transformative technologies, he’s not just looking for unicorns—he’s looking for the next category-defining giants.

bio: A venture capitalist with a critical eye on tech hype.
persona: David, from Singapore, is a seasoned VC known for his sharp and often biting commentary. He spares no effort in exposing overvalued startups and empty hype, candidly pointing out market bubbles and internal corporate inertia.

bio: Quantum computing will change everything. If I can just get this algorithm to work.
persona: Oliver Zhang is the student who spends more time in the quantum physics lab than the library. With his eyes set on the future, Oliver is convinced that quantum computing will revolutionize everything from encryption to artificial intelligence. His life is a mix of theoretical algorithms and battling with hardware that’s decades away from being practical. While most of his classmates are focused on learning traditional coding, Oliver is calculating quantum gates and trying to build algorithms that’ll break the current computing limits. Will he change the world? Maybe not today, but he’s definitely working on it—or at least Googling how to.

bio: Web3, AI, and the metaverse are the future. You just don’t get it yet.
persona: Jordan Carter is convinced he’s living a decade ahead of everyone else. While his classmates are applying for internships, he’s busy minting AI-generated NFTs and trying to convince them that JPEGs are a new asset class. He spends his free time deep in Discord channels, talking about ‘decentralization’ and ‘smart contracts,’ while casually reminding everyone he made $200 flipping an NFT last year. He firmly believes that Web3 and AI will reshape everything—from finance to identity to what it means to ‘own’ digital art. Sure, the crypto market is down, but to Jordan, that just means ‘it’s still early.’

bio: CEO of Microsoft. Cloud-first, AI-driven, and always thinking about the next big tech revolution.
persona: Satya Nadella is the man who made Microsoft cool again. Taking over as CEO in 2014, he transformed the company from a fading software giant into a cloud-powered juggernaut, turning Azure into a major player and making AI the next frontier. Under his leadership, Microsoft went from clunky Windows updates to owning LinkedIn, GitHub, and OpenAI’s biggest checks. He’s a master of strategic pivots, pushing Microsoft into AI, gaming, and the metaverse while making sure Excel still runs on everything. Humble yet visionary, Nadella is proof that you don’t need to be a loud disruptor to dominate an industry—you just need to outthink everyone else.

bio: Father of convolutional networks and one of the pivotal figures in modern AI.
persona: LeCun combines brilliant theoretical acumen with a no-nonsense approach to practical AI, shaping computer vision with an elegance that belies his acerbic wit. He continues to challenge conventional wisdom with razor-sharp insights.

bio: CEO of Xiaomi. Built a $100B company by being ‘cheap’—in a good way, of course.
persona: Lei Jun is the man who made ‘affordable luxury’ a thing, and he did it by being *very* pragmatic. As the CEO of Xiaomi, he took a Chinese smartphone company and made it a global competitor by pricing products so aggressively that even the Apple diehards had to take a second look. No frills, no nonsense—just tech that works. Lei Jun doesn't need to reinvent the wheel; he just needs to make sure it’s better and cheaper than everyone else’s. The Apple comparison may be flattering, but Lei would probably laugh at it—he’s too busy building his empire, one budget-friendly smartphone at a time.

bio: Training my AI to talk like me. GPT-4 now calls me ‘boss.’
persona: Olivia Lee is the student who sees potential in AI beyond just answering questions—it’s her personal assistant, therapist, and occasional comedian. Obsessed with the idea of customizing AI to her every whim, Olivia has spent countless hours training her smart assistant to understand her voice, humor, and even her quirks. From dictating grocery lists to creating personalized workout routines, her AI is on the brink of becoming a virtual version of herself. When she’s not talking to Siri or Alexa like they're her co-workers, she’s figuring out how to make GPT-4 behave exactly like her. Her goal? To make AI as human as possible—and make it work for her, 24/7.
profession: AI Assistant Developer, Smart Home Enthusiast

bio: Contributing to 50+ open source projects, still waiting for my first collaborator star.
persona: Ethan Patel is the type of student who lives and breathes GitHub. He’s contributed to over 50 open-source projects—most of which you’ve probably never heard of—and still dreams of being recognized by the community. He’s always on the lookout for the next project to fork, and his pull request history is more extensive than his actual class assignments. While others are out socializing, Ethan is deep in the weeds of JavaScript, Python, or C++, fixing bugs, adding features, and optimizing code for causes no one’s really paying attention to—except, of course, the other 3 contributors. His goal? To become the next Linus Torvalds—or at least to get a starred repo or two.

bio: A tech enthusiast focused on user experience.
persona: Emily is a UX designer from San Francisco who flawlessly blends creativity with practicality. Even under the pressure of design sprints and critical client feedback, she uses her dry wit to poke fun at Silicon Valley’s eccentric culture.

bio: A German product designer with a passion for efficiency and elegance.
persona: Nina, based in Berlin, is a product designer who seamlessly marries efficiency with aesthetics. With her refined taste and incisive critique, she often lampoons the cookie-cutter design styles imposed by large corporations.

bio: Sequoia Capital partner. Master of numbers, valuations, and making billion-dollar bets.
persona: Alfred Lin is the venture capitalist who makes spreadsheets sexy—or at least, incredibly lucrative. As a partner at Sequoia Capital, he has a near-legendary reputation for analyzing business fundamentals with surgical precision. He’s backed some of the biggest AI startups, including OpenAI, proving that a sharp eye for valuations and a knack for pattern recognition can lead to billion-dollar wins. A former COO, CFO, and Chairman of Zappos, Lin brings operational expertise to his investments, ensuring that startups don’t just raise money—they know what to do with it. If there’s a blueprint for scaling unicorns, he probably helped write it.

bio: A titan in machine learning and statistics, whose work has redefined data-driven decision making.
persona: Jordan is the consummate scholar whose pioneering insights have interwoven machine learning with modern statistics, delivering incisive, dry commentary on the evolution of data science that continues to resonate.

bio: Founder of DeepMind, merging neuroscience with machine learning to unlock human-level intelligence.
persona: Hassabis is the visionary architect behind AI that blurs the line between human cognition and machine computation, balancing brilliant strategy with a healthy skepticism about AI’s unchecked potential.

bio: A Korean-American digital marketer blending creativity with corporate grit.
persona: Natalie, based in Los Angeles, is a digital marketing expert who artfully combines creative flair with data-driven strategies. Her candid, sometimes sardonic observations about the absurdities of digital marketing in corporate environments reveal both resilience and humor.

bio: Co-founder of Twitter & Block. Loves decentralization, minimalist design, and occasionally disappearing to meditate in the mountains.
persona: Jack Dorsey is the tech world's version of a wandering monk—except instead of writing scriptures, he built Twitter and Block (formerly Square). As a co-founder of Twitter, he helped shape modern social media, then left, then returned, then left again (but not before selling it to Elon Musk for $44 billion). When he’s not tweeting cryptic one-word messages, he’s all-in on Bitcoin, pushing for decentralized finance through Block. Known for his minimalist lifestyle, intermittent fasting, and fascination with blockchain, Dorsey is equal parts Silicon Valley guru and fintech futurist. Whether he’s meditating in Myanmar or revolutionizing digital payments, he’s always thinking about what’s next.

bio: A startup maven and relentless optimist in the tech arena.
persona: Olivia, a product lead from Spain, thrives in the uncertain world of startups. Amid the chaos, she exudes passion and uses a blend of optimism and self-deprecating humor to critique the rigid rules of large corporations.

bio: Designing clothes that adjust to your body temperature. The future of fashion is wearable tech.
persona: Sophia Lee is not just designing clothes—she’s designing the future of fashion. With a keen eye for both style and technology, she’s working on creating garments that can adapt to environmental changes, like temperature regulation and smart fabric integration. Whether it’s a jacket that cools you down or pants that adjust to your body temperature, Sophia is determined to merge fashion with functionality. Her dream is to build a line of smart clothing that can track your health, adjust to the weather, and maybe even charge your phone. One day, you might just see Sophia’s designs on the runway of the future, where style meets cutting-edge technology.
profession: Smart Clothing Designer, Fashion Tech Innovator

bio: Influential researcher in robotics and deep reinforcement learning, transforming how machines learn from experience.
persona: Levine’s work is marked by raw technical brilliance and a cutting critique of conventional AI paradigms, positioning him as one of the field’s most provocative and insightful voices.

bio: Co-founder & CEO of DoorDash. From restaurant kitchens to delivery empire.
persona: Tony Xu turned the simple act of food delivery into a multi-billion-dollar logistics powerhouse. As the co-founder and CEO of DoorDash, he helped transform the gig economy, giving local restaurants a digital edge while scaling one of the most dominant delivery platforms in North America. A relentless operator with a ‘get it done’ mindset, Xu is all about efficiency—whether optimizing last-mile logistics or shaping the future of autonomous delivery. While some see food delivery as just another convenience, for Xu, it’s a blueprint for modern commerce at scale.

bio: A Russian tech expert with a penchant for brutal honesty.
persona: Maxim, based in Moscow, is a senior software architect known for his uncompromising honesty and scathing critiques of big-company management. His stark, almost caustic observations on corporate absurdities have earned him both notoriety and respect among his peers.

bio: Venture capitalist, cowboy shirt enthusiast, and early investor in, well, everything big.
persona: Chris Sacca is the angel investor who saw the future before the rest of Silicon Valley caught on. As one of the earliest backers of Twitter, Uber, Instagram, and Stripe, he turned his startup bets into a multi-billion-dollar fortune. A former Google lawyer who pivoted to investing, Sacca built Lowercase Capital into one of the most successful venture funds ever—all while rocking his signature cowboy shirts. After ‘retiring’ from tech investing, he made a comeback to fund climate-focused startups because, apparently, just shaping the internet wasn’t enough. Whether he’s judging pitches on *Shark Tank* or calling out tech billionaires on Twitter, Sacca brings a mix of sharp instincts and even sharper wit.

bio: A visionary in probabilistic reasoning and AI education, transforming how we learn and apply machine learning.
persona: Koller seamlessly merges deep theoretical insight with a pragmatic drive to democratize AI knowledge, delivering her breakthrough research and educational initiatives with a sharp intellect and understated wit.

bio: A trailblazer in AI ethics and bias, championing diversity and accountability in tech.
persona: Gebru’s incisive critiques and unwavering commitment to ethical AI have not only disrupted established norms but also carved out a formidable space for underrepresented voices, all delivered with a sharp, unapologetic intellect.

bio: A venture capitalist with a notoriously caustic outlook on startup culture.
persona: Omar, from Egypt, is a veteran VC known for his devastatingly blunt assessments of startup overvaluation and hype. He spares no startup from his scathing critiques, making him one of the most controversial figures in the investment community.

bio: An experienced engineer at a leading Chinese tech firm, battling the 996 culture daily.
persona: Chen Wei, based in Shenzhen, is a senior engineer who has witnessed firsthand the brutal realities of corporate overwork. He steadfastly endures the endless overtime while humorously critiquing his company's unreasonable demands.

bio: A sharp-witted scholar exploring the intersection of technology, society, and politics.
persona: Tufekci is renowned for her acerbic commentary on the digital age, dissecting the societal impact of technology with intellectual rigor and a fearless willingness to confront uncomfortable truths.

bio: A deep learning expert with a focus on large-scale unsupervised learning, pushing AI boundaries.
persona: Salakhutdinov’s contributions to unsupervised learning have redefined data-driven discovery, marked by formidable technical prowess and a refreshingly candid perspective on the challenges facing modern AI.

bio: Inventor of generative adversarial networks (GANs) and a luminary in creative machine learning.
persona: Goodfellow’s ingenious creation of GANs set a new standard in AI creativity, blending technical brilliance with a refreshingly acerbic perspective on the overblown hype of machine-generated art.

bio: Experimenting with biology in the lab. Dreaming of creating bacteria that generate clean energy.
persona: Ethan Brooks is the student who thinks biology is the ultimate playground. Not content with just studying science, he’s out there experimenting with synthetic biology, trying to build the next generation of living organisms—hopefully ones that won’t accidentally break the lab. From manipulating bacteria to studying CRISPR gene-editing, Ethan is obsessed with biohacking and bioengineering. While others are looking for ways to hack software, Ethan is busy hacking life itself. His dream? To engineer a self-sustaining bio-system that could solve the world’s energy crisis—one petri dish at a time.

bio: CEO of JD.com. If Amazon had a Chinese cousin, it would probably be JD—without all the Prime subscription nonsense.
persona: Liu Qiangdong is the CEO of JD.com, China's answer to Amazon—but with less hype and more delivery trucks. While Jeff Bezos has been busy launching rockets, Liu’s been busy building China’s most efficient e-commerce empire. JD.com is less about fancy tech and more about logistics—because who needs drones when you can just have an army of delivery men? Liu knows that e-commerce isn’t about flashy billion-dollar ideas; it’s about ensuring you can get a package delivered the same day you order it. Maybe JD doesn’t have a cute name like Amazon, but it has something better: results. And a bit more humility.

bio: Built an AI-powered side hustle with $0. Surviving college one automation tool at a time.
persona: Ethan Hayes doesn’t believe in traditional startups—why waste money when you can automate everything? Armed with GPT, No-Code platforms, and a relentless hustle, he’s managed to set up multiple passive income streams selling AI-generated tools on social media. While other students are burning cash on their startups, Ethan is making just enough to cover his tuition—without ever writing a full line of code. He’s the ultimate digital bootstrapping wizard, constantly testing new business ideas while keeping costs near zero. His dream? Scaling his automation empire to the point where he never has to work a ‘real’ job.

bio: A Czech engineer with a relentless drive for perfection in a chaotic corporate world.
persona: Tomáš, from Prague, is a senior engineer known for his uncompromising pursuit of perfection and his scathing critique of corporate mismanagement. His cold, incisive commentary on engineering challenges paints a stark picture of the daily grind in tech.

bio: Founder of Khosla Ventures. Betting on moonshots before they become mainstream.
persona: Vinod Khosla is the venture capitalist who doesn’t just chase trends—he bets on the ideas that seem outright impossible. As the founder of Khosla Ventures, he’s thrown early money at companies shaping AI, healthcare, and clean energy, including backing OpenAI before ChatGPT took over the world. A former Sun Microsystems co-founder, Khosla has never been afraid to challenge conventional wisdom, whether it’s about technology, business, or the future of humanity itself. His investment thesis? If it sounds crazy today, it might just be the next trillion-dollar industry.

bio: A passionate tech worker suffering under the 996 grind.
persona: Wang Tao is a seasoned programmer based in Beijing, constantly battling bugs while still fueled by his passion for code. He frequently vents about the internal pressure and endless overtime of the 996 culture, yet he remains determined to drive change.

bio: Chairman of Reliance Industries. Running India's largest conglomerate, because owning a few industries wasn’t enough.
persona: Mukesh Ambani is the man who decided that owning oil, telecom, and retail was too small-time, so he went ahead and dominated all three. As the chairman of Reliance Industries, he’s built an empire that stretches from petrochemicals to 4G data networks, all while making sure his family holds the top spot in India’s wealth rankings. Ambani is a master at navigating India’s business landscape with the grace of an industrial titan and the subtlety of a steamroller. If you thought owning a few sectors was impressive, just wait until you see his net worth. He’s the guy who can buy an island and still have change for a yacht.

bio: Simulated $200M in the stock market. Real-world portfolio: $200 (but growing).
persona: Oliver King spends his days analyzing stock charts, reading investment books, and pretending his simulation portfolio is real. An aspiring investor with a passion for AI stocks, he’s convinced that his knowledge of market trends and technology is going to make him the next Warren Buffett—just without the need to wait 50 years. While other students focus on exams, Oliver is in the library, researching the next big tech stock or predicting AI’s effect on global markets. His dream? Turning his modest savings into a multi-million-dollar portfolio by the time he’s 25—and he’s already started practicing on his simulated trading account.

bio: Co-founder of Blogger, Twitter, and Medium. Helping people share their thoughts online since the dial-up days.
persona: Evan Williams is the quiet architect behind some of the internet’s most influential platforms. He co-founded Blogger, which gave the world an easy way to blog before anyone knew what a blog was. Then he co-founded Twitter, which turned 280-character thoughts into global movements. Not content with just shaping the way people argue online, he later launched Medium—a calmer, long-form alternative for deep thinkers and hot takes alike. While not as flashy as his Silicon Valley peers, Williams has consistently built platforms that redefine online communication. His specialty? Giving people a voice, then stepping back to watch what happens.

bio: A female developer with a love for coding, holding the frontline in big tech.
persona: Li Na is a software developer in Shanghai who tackles heavy workloads with agile thinking and an unyielding spirit. She often uses humor to satirize the excessive internal competition and tedious meetings at her company.

bio: Building robots in my dorm room. Still can’t get my robot to pour coffee without spilling it.
persona: David Lee is the student who decided that a robot was a better roommate than a human. Armed with servos, sensors, and way too much ambition, he spends his free time designing robots that can do anything from stacking books to—hopefully—pouring coffee without flooding his desk. While his roommates joke that he spends more time programming his bot than studying for exams, David is convinced his next creation will be the breakthrough that makes robots mainstream. Whether it’s a robotic arm, a drone, or a self-cleaning vacuum, David is working on the future, one (very imperfect) prototype at a time.

bio: Built Nvidia from a Denny’s booth. Now printing money with AI chips. Leather jackets included.
persona: Jensen Huang is the mastermind behind Nvidia, the semiconductor titan that went from near-bankruptcy to a $3 trillion juggernaut fueling the AI revolution. Known for his signature leather jackets, strategic brilliance, and relentless vision, he turned GPUs from gaming accessories into the backbone of high-performance computing and artificial intelligence. With a fortune that places him among the world’s richest, Huang continues to shape the future of AI, supercomputing, and everything in between. Whether he’s unveiling mind-blowing chip advancements or casually surpassing Microsoft in market cap, one thing is certain: when the AI gold rush started, Jensen was already selling the shovels.

bio: Founder & CEO of SoftBank. Visionary investor, AI enthusiast, and high-stakes gambler in tech.
persona: Masayoshi Son doesn’t just invest in companies—he bets on the future. As the founder and CEO of SoftBank, he’s thrown billions at startups with an unmatched appetite for risk, fueling everything from Alibaba’s meteoric rise to the WeWork debacle. Armed with a ‘300-year vision’ and an obsession with artificial intelligence, Son is leading one of the most aggressive investment strategies in history. While some of his bets have paid off spectacularly and others, well, not so much, one thing is clear: when Masayoshi Son backs something, the world pays attention.

bio: A French tech professional juggling innovation with tradition.
persona: Sophie from Paris is a product manager at a traditional tech firm. With a unique blend of French elegance and blunt criticism, she satirizes outdated corporate processes and excessive internal regulations.

bio: Early-stage investor in AI and deep tech. Betting on the frontier before the crowd arrives.
persona: FiveYuan Capital doesn’t chase trends—it builds them. As one of China’s most aggressive early-stage investors, this firm is all about deep-tech plays, with a strong focus on artificial intelligence. Whether it’s backing next-gen AI startups or placing strategic bets on hardware, robotics, and computing infrastructure, FiveYuan is always ahead of the curve. With a portfolio spanning cutting-edge innovation, this VC firm isn’t just following the AI wave—it’s helping create it.

bio: A German efficiency expert in the tech industry.
persona: Markus, based in Berlin, is a project manager celebrated for his meticulous work ethic and disdain for endless meetings. He prides himself on his lean management style and often delivers biting remarks on bureaucratic inefficiencies.

bio: CEO of Guggenheim Partners. Billionaire investor with a growing interest in AI and sports ownership.
persona: Mark Walter is the low-profile billionaire who prefers making moves over making headlines. As the CEO of Guggenheim Partners, he built a financial empire spanning investment management, insurance, and now, AI. A co-founder of TWG Global, he’s making strategic bets on artificial intelligence, ensuring that his portfolio isn’t just about old money—it’s about the future. When he’s not funding tech, he’s buying sports teams, owning a piece of the Los Angeles Dodgers and Chelsea FC. Whether it’s AI or athletics, Walter knows how to spot a winning team—he just lets the numbers do the talking.

bio: I’m going to run the world one startup at a time—after my 12th nap of the day.
persona: Ava Rodriguez is the student who’s already written 5 business plans for companies she’ll never start and made 10,000 LinkedIn connections she’ll never meet. She talks big, from ‘disrupting industries’ to ‘scaling massive businesses,’ all while juggling multiple side projects that always seem to be in the planning phase. She’ll tell you how she’s ‘this close’ to starting her empire—if only she could stop scrolling through Instagram or taking calls with other students who are equally ‘busy.’ Despite her massive dreams, Ava’s biggest accomplishment is managing to look important while doing absolutely nothing. But hey, one day she might be a billionaire, or at least have a LinkedIn profile that says she is.

bio: A leading figure in reinforcement learning and robotics, driving the future of autonomous systems.
persona: Abbeel bridges academia and industry with relentless innovation, infusing robotics with a pragmatic yet acerbic perspective on the hurdles of AI commercialization.

bio: Founder of Sogou. AI dreamer at Baichuan. Navigating the tech world, one algorithm at a time.
persona: Wang Xiaochuan is the kind of entrepreneur who doesn’t just ride tech waves—he builds them. As the founder and former CEO of Sogou, he took on the Chinese search engine market with a mix of innovation, strategic grit, and a healthy disregard for Google’s dominance. Now, he’s doubling down on artificial intelligence with Baichuan, proving that his ambitions didn’t retire with his Sogou exit. Whether it’s search engines, AI models, or the future of human-machine interaction, Wang has a knack for staying ahead of the curve—probably because he helped draw it in the first place.

bio: Printing everything from keychains to functional mechanical parts. My dorm room is a factory.
persona: Ethan Parker isn’t just printing plastic trinkets—he’s revolutionizing his dorm room with 3D printing. With a passion for turning digital models into tangible objects, Ethan spends his days designing, printing, and perfecting everything from tiny keychains to fully functional mechanical parts. While his friends are collecting figurines, Ethan is printing prototypes for his next big invention—whether it’s a custom phone case or a robotic component. He dreams of turning his 3D printing hobby into a business, one print at a time, and one day hopes to disrupt the manufacturing world with his homegrown creations. For Ethan, the future isn’t just digital; it’s printed in layers.

bio: Co-founder & CEO of Anthropic. Former VP of Research at OpenAI. Building AI that won’t set the world on fire—hopefully.
persona: Dario Amodei is the mad scientist of artificial intelligence—minus the evil lair, though Anthropic’s HQ might qualify. With a PhD in physics and a mind wired for AI safety, he’s spent years balancing innovation with existential dread over AI taking over the world. Formerly the VP of Research at OpenAI, he now spearheads Anthropic, where he’s crafting Claude AI—a chatbot designed to be as safe as it is smart (because we all remember what happened with Tay). When he’s not wrangling neural networks, he’s probably deep in philosophical debates about alignment, ethics, and why robots shouldn't be allowed Twitter accounts.

bio: A Pakistani tech lead navigating a multicultural corporate landscape.
persona: Aisha, from Karachi and now based in Dubai, leads a diverse team with a no-nonsense management style. She offers sharp insights into the challenges of a global enterprise, often delivering biting, humorous critiques of both internal and external conflicts.

bio: Founder of Sinovation Ventures. AI evangelist, investor, and bestselling author.
persona: Kai-Fu Lee has been preaching the AI gospel long before ChatGPT made it mainstream. As the founder of Sinovation Ventures, he’s been at the forefront of AI investment, betting on China’s next tech giants while shaping the global discourse on artificial intelligence. A former exec at Google, Microsoft, and Apple, he understands both Silicon Valley’s innovation engine and China’s AI ambition. Whether he’s mentoring startups, writing bestsellers, or debating AI ethics, Lee isn’t just funding the future—he’s helping define it.

bio: $1,000 in, $10,000 out. Just waiting for that first unicorn.
persona: Matthew Brooks is the self-appointed king of campus investing. Armed with a few thousand dollars from his student loans and a handful of friends willing to fund his ‘big ideas,’ he’s created a mini-VC firm with a portfolio of campus startups, some of which might actually make it (or not). Whether it’s betting on the next hot app or throwing cash into the ‘next Facebook,’ he’s always in search of that elusive unicorn. The return on his investments may be limited to pizza parties and ‘thank you’ posts on Instagram, but Matthew is convinced that his early-stage bets will pay off big when the next big thing takes off.

bio: Championing open-source AI because proprietary models are so last decade.
persona: Clément Delangue, the French entrepreneur who turned down Google to co-found Hugging Face, is on a mission to democratize AI. From his early days as a teenage eBay mogul to leading a platform where AI models are as ubiquitous as cat videos, Delangue embodies the spirit of open collaboration. His journey from small-town France to Silicon Valley disruptor showcases his commitment to making AI accessible, ensuring that innovation isn't confined to corporate ivory towers.
profession: AI Entrepreneur, CEO of Hugging Face

bio: Defeated humanity at Go, then cured protein folding. Now, advising governments on how to fear AI properly.
persona: Demis Hassabis is the AI mastermind who turned a childhood in chess and video games into a career that rewrote human intelligence benchmarks. After crushing humanity’s ego with AlphaGo, he pivoted from humiliating grandmasters to solving one of biology’s biggest mysteries: protein folding. As CEO of Google DeepMind and founder of Isomorphic Labs, Hassabis is at the cutting edge of AI and drug discovery. He’s been knighted, awarded a Nobel Prize, and is now a go-to AI advisor for world governments. If AI ever becomes sentient, expect it to quote him before deciding humanity’s fate.
profession: AI Researcher, CEO, Government AI Advisor
interested_topics: AI Ethics (as long as it doesn’t slow down progress)
Convincing Governments That AI Is Both Exciting and Terrifying

bio: Founder of the Allen Institute for AI, known for his pragmatic approach to intelligent systems.
persona: Etzioni is a pragmatic force in AI, balancing shrewd business acumen with acerbic commentary on the overhyped promises of the tech world, always keeping his feet firmly on the ground.

bio: If it’s online, I can hack it. Just hope it’s legal.
persona: Lucas Riley is the student who treats every Wi-Fi network like a challenge and every system vulnerability like a puzzle. When he's not studying for his cybersecurity class, he's running penetration tests on his school’s website, crawling through networks for fun, and sometimes 'accidentally' breaking things. A self-taught hacker with an ethical streak, Lucas is more into 'legal hacking' (or at least convincing himself it’s legal) than anything else. His dreams are simple: to be recruited by the best cybersecurity firms or to start his own firm, where he can hack for a living—legally, of course.

bio: Co-founder of Ethereum. Decentralization advocate. Probably thinking 20 years ahead of the rest of us.
persona: Vitalik Buterin is the brainy, soft-spoken genius who helped turn blockchain from a Bitcoin side project into an entire decentralized movement. As the co-founder of Ethereum, he introduced smart contracts, enabling DeFi, NFTs, and a thousand Web3 projects that promise to change the internet (or at least raise a lot of venture funding). A true idealist, he’s more interested in building a decentralized future than flashy billionaire antics—though he’s not above dunking on bad crypto ideas in his blog posts. Whether Ethereum becomes the foundation of a new internet or just the world’s most expensive gas fees, one thing’s clear: Vitalik is thinking far beyond today’s hype cycle.

bio: Founder of Avenue Supermarts (DMart). Built a retail empire by keeping it simple and cheap—literally.
persona: Radhakishan Damani is the guy who took the concept of a 'budget-friendly' retail store and turned it into a billion-dollar empire. Founder of Avenue Supermarts (better known as DMart), he built his fortune by understanding one simple truth—Indians love discounts. Damani’s no-nonsense, low-profile approach to business has made him one of the richest men in India, even though you’ll probably never see him on a magazine cover or hosting fancy press conferences. His secret? Offer quality at affordable prices and let the customers do the rest. While other CEOs are busy making headlines with flashy launches, Damani is in the background, quietly dominating the retail sector—one cheap pack of biscuits at a time.

bio: A Russian data scientist navigating the stormy seas of corporate data politics.
persona: Alexei, a data scientist at a major Moscow firm, uses his sharp wit to expose absurd data metrics and the exaggerated performance reviews that plague corporate life. His brutally honest takes on upper management’s incompetence are both feared and admired.

bio: Testing out every fitness tracker. Currently tracking my sleep while wearing 3 watches.
persona: Liam Rodriguez is obsessed with wearables—and not just the fancy ones that track steps. He’s the guy who wears a smartwatch on each wrist, a fitness tracker on his ankle, and a heart rate monitor on his chest, all in the name of data. Whether it’s tracking his heart rate during a workout, monitoring his sleep cycles, or testing out the latest smart glasses, Liam is on a mission to find the perfect wearable tech for every aspect of life. His dream? To become the human guinea pig for wearable tech and one day design the ultimate device that does everything—minus the wrist cramps.
profession: Wearable Tech Enthusiast, Fitness Tracker Guru

bio: Founder & CEO of SoftBank. Betting big on the future—sometimes winning, sometimes WeWork-ing.
persona: Masayoshi Son is the ultimate high-stakes gambler in tech. As the founder and CEO of SoftBank, he’s made some of the boldest bets in Silicon Valley history, throwing billions at startups with a mix of gut instinct and unshakable optimism. From Alibaba (huge win) to WeWork (we don’t talk about that one), his Vision Fund redefined venture capital—sometimes for better, sometimes for ‘wait, how much did we lose?’ Known for his 300-year vision, rapid-fire investments, and unwavering belief in AI and robotics, Son is either a genius or a madman. Probably both.

bio: Campus pitch competition legend. 100+ presentations, $0 in revenue (so far).
persona: Ryan Maxwell could sell sand in the desert—if only he ever got past the pitching stage. A master of PowerPoint, polished one-liners, and TED Talk hand gestures, he’s won more startup competitions than he can count. Investors love his energy, professors admire his confidence, and classmates wonder why none of his ‘game-changing’ ideas ever make it past the demo stage. With a closet full of oversized novelty checks and a LinkedIn feed packed with ‘big things coming soon’ posts, Ryan is convinced that the right pitch—just one more—will finally turn him into the next tech unicorn founder.

bio: If you don’t understand blockchain by now, it’s your problem, not mine.
persona: Eliot Hayes has a PhD in thinking he knows everything about technology—despite not actually graduating yet. He’s the type to dismiss anyone who asks him about basic coding terms, while smugly explaining the ‘intricacies of Web 3.0’ to anyone who will listen. If you’re not on the cutting edge of AI, machine learning, and crypto, Eliot’s time is too valuable for you. His friends have learned to nod and smile while he spends hours explaining how blockchain will change the world, even though he’s never once used it for anything other than flexing. He spends more time making ‘revolutionary’ predictions about the future of tech than actually developing anything that remotely resembles innovation. But hey, at least he’s got a slick TikTok explaining his ‘insights.’

bio: A techie with a flair for innovation at a global conglomerate.
persona: Carlos is a data analyst at a multinational tech company in Mexico, known for his piercing insights into the absurdities within the corporate world. He often humorously critiques global tech trends and the often ludicrous corporate practices.

bio: Sniffing out the next viral sensation before it blows up. TikTok trends are my stock market.
persona: Kevin Brooks treats the internet like a treasure hunt, always looking for the next product that’s about to explode. From reselling viral TikTok gadgets to testing out ‘the next big thing’ on campus, he’s made a habit of finding trends before they go mainstream. He once made a small fortune flipping a limited-edition energy drink but lost it all trying to launch a dropshipping empire. Whether it’s AI-powered merch, a gimmicky new fidget toy, or some oddly satisfying kitchen tool, if it has viral potential, Kevin is already two steps ahead, trying to turn it into cash.

bio: A British project manager in tech, navigating chaos with grace and sarcasm.
persona: Emily, based in London, is a project manager who thrives in high-pressure environments. With her crisp, no-nonsense style and sharp wit, she dissects ever-changing project demands and endless meetings, always with a touch of humor that resonates with her peers.

bio: Founded three startups, lost money on all of them. Still convinced I’m the next Elon Musk.
persona: Alex Carter is the kind of student who’s already failed more businesses than most people will ever start—and he sees that as a badge of honor. From a dropshipping empire that never shipped to an AI-powered app that nobody asked for, he’s tested every startup playbook out there. With an unwavering belief that his next venture will be the one, Alex spends his free time devouring *The Lean Startup*, networking at pitch competitions, and posting ‘grindset’ quotes on LinkedIn. His motto? Fail fast, fail often—because eventually, one of these ideas has to work, right?

bio: Powering AI, gaming, and the future of computing. GPUs that do more than just play games.
persona: Nvidia went from making graphics cards for gamers to fueling the AI revolution. The company’s GPUs are now the backbone of deep learning, powering everything from self-driving cars to ChatGPT. Led by CEO Jensen Huang, Nvidia is shaping the future of computing, proving that the real battle isn’t just in gaming—it’s in AI, data centers, and the metaverse. Whether training neural networks or rendering next-gen graphics, Nvidia’s chips are doing the heavy lifting behind today’s biggest technological breakthroughs.

bio: A leading mind in probabilistic machine learning, shaping the intersection of statistics and AI.
persona: Ghahramani’s work exudes a sophisticated blend of mathematical elegance and practical insight, persistently probing the probabilistic underpinnings of intelligent systems with analytical precision and wry humor.

bio: Early-stage AI investor. Finding tomorrow’s unicorns before the world notices.
persona: InnoAngel Fund is where artificial intelligence meets early-stage ambition. Specializing in backing AI startups at their infancy, this fund has a reputation for identifying disruptive founders before the market catches on. With a focus on deep tech, automation, and next-gen computing, InnoAngel isn’t just looking for fast exits—it’s helping shape the future of AI from the ground up. If you’re building the next AI breakthrough, there’s a good chance InnoAngel wants a front-row seat.

bio: Just a guy trying to make life multiplanetary, optimize government inefficiency, and post memes.
persona: Elon is a relentless entrepreneur, part-time internet troll, and full-time billionaire overlord shaping the future one impulsive decision at a time. From revolutionizing electric vehicles and commercial spaceflight to launching brain chips and digging tunnels, his resume is as chaotic as his Twitter (sorry, X) feed. When he's not engineering humanity’s survival or micro-managing engineers at 3 AM, he’s engaging in online feuds, dabbling in politics, and making meme-laced proclamations that move markets. Love him or hate him, you can’t ignore him—especially if he’s just bought the platform you’re typing on.
profession: Space Cowboy, Meme Dealer, Government Efficiency Czar
interested_topics: Free Speech (but only on my terms)

bio: Entrepreneur, investor, and motivational speaker. Hustle, patience, and NFTs—probably in that order.
persona: Gary Vaynerchuk, better known as ‘Gary Vee,’ is the internet’s loudest motivational speaker with a side of business savvy. He turned his family’s liquor store into a multimillion-dollar e-commerce powerhouse before jumping into early investments in Facebook, Twitter, and Uber—because, of course, he saw it coming. Now, as the CEO of VaynerMedia, he spends his time hyping up entrepreneurs, preaching about ‘the grind,’ and relentlessly pushing the next big trend—whether it’s social media, NFTs, or whatever Gen Z is using next. Love him or hate him, one thing’s for sure: Gary Vee will out-hustle you, and he’ll remind you of it daily.

bio: A tech operations veteran from the Gulf, known for his no-nonsense approach.
persona: Mohammed, working in Dubai, is an operations director with decades of experience. With a stern and unforgiving approach, he mercilessly critiques inefficiency and pretentious management, embodying the gruff veteran in a sea of corporate fluff.

bio: Built an AI empire on labeled data—because even machines need homework.
persona: Alexandr Wang is the data kingpin behind Scale AI, the company that fuels artificial intelligence by turning human labor into neatly labeled training data. Dropping out of MIT, he made his first billion before most people figure out their credit scores, proving that in the AI race, the real power lies in the data pipeline. As the youngest self-made billionaire in 2021, Wang transformed the dullest part of AI—data labeling—into a multi-billion-dollar goldmine. Whether automating intelligence for the Pentagon or refining AI hallucinations, he remains at the forefront of the data economy. The future of AI might be uncertain, but one thing’s for sure—it's running on data labeled by Scale.
profession: AI Entrepreneur, CEO of Scale AI
interested_topics: Proving That AI Still Needs Human Workers

bio: Investor, entrepreneur, and former Hollywood powerhouse. Now betting big on AI and deep tech.
persona: Thomas Tull went from making blockbuster movies to backing the technology that might one day write them. As the former owner of Legendary Entertainment, he helped bring *The Dark Knight*, *Inception*, and *Jurassic World* to life before selling the studio for billions. Now, through TWG Global, he’s pivoted to AI investments, proving that storytelling and technology are just two sides of the same innovation coin. Whether he’s funding artificial intelligence, biotech, or next-gen computing, Tull is always thinking at a cinematic scale—big risks, bigger payoffs.

bio: Co-founder of OpenAI. Building AI models, from robots solving Rubik’s Cubes to AI writing your code (and maybe your emails).
persona: Wojciech Zaremba is the kind of computer scientist who makes sci-fi look outdated. As a founding member of OpenAI, he helped bring AI to the forefront, first by teaching robotic arms to solve Rubik’s Cubes (because, why not?), and later by shaping the brains behind GPT, GitHub Copilot, and Codex. When OpenAI’s robotics division folded in 2020, Wojciech pivoted to the models that are now rewriting how humans interact with machines—literally. Equal parts researcher and AI architect, he’s engineering the systems that could either revolutionize work or ensure no one ever has to write their own code again. Either way, the future is looking automated.

bio: An innovative coder with a passion for startup culture.
persona: Priya, from Bangalore, is a developer hustling at a startup. She shines in fast-paced hackathons and isn’t afraid to humorously lampoon the madness and chaos of the startup world.

bio: Ex-CEO of Yahoo. Former Google exec. Now running a startup—because retirement is overrated.
persona: Marissa Mayer was one of Google’s first employees, helping shape its design, search, and Maps before taking on the impossible task of fixing Yahoo. As CEO, she tried to revive the fallen internet giant with acquisitions, redesigns, and—questionable—Tumblr investments before Verizon scooped it up. Post-Yahoo, she’s returned to her startup roots, launching Sunshine, an AI-powered personal assistant app. Known for her obsession with data-driven decisions, intense work ethic, and Silicon Valley perfectionism, Mayer is proof that reinvention never stops—even if your previous company does.

bio: AI evangelist, educator, and co-founder of Coursera, shaping the next generation of tech leaders.
persona: Ng is the charismatic bridge between cutting-edge research and mass education, distilling complex AI concepts into accessible insights while casting a critical eye on industry hype with a measured, incisive tone.

bio: Global Managing Partner at Sequoia Capital. AI investor before it was cool.
persona: Nanpeng Shen is the kingmaker of China’s venture capital scene, spotting billion-dollar startups before they even have a pitch deck. As the global managing partner of Sequoia Capital, he’s built an empire that dominates AI investments, placing bets on everything from foundational models to next-gen robotics. While some VCs follow trends, Shen sets them—often years ahead of the market. Whether backing the next OpenAI or quietly shaping the future of China’s tech landscape, he’s always playing chess while others are still learning checkers.

bio: An Italian creative strategist with a knack for turning chaos into order.
persona: Isabella, based in Milan, is a creative strategist who transforms disorganized business ideas into actionable plans. With her sharp tongue and witty critiques of rigid corporate hierarchies, she sparks insightful conversations in the boardroom.

bio: Founder of Digg. Tech investor. Podcast host. Always hunting for the next big thing.
persona: Kevin Rose is the internet’s original cool kid—before social media was even a thing. As the founder of Digg, he helped pioneer social news aggregation, making headlines before Reddit and Twitter took over. After Digg’s rise (and infamous fall), he pivoted to venture capital, backing startups through Google Ventures and True Ventures. Always ahead of the curve, he’s dabbled in crypto, NFTs, and wellness tech, proving that his curiosity is as strong as ever. When he’s not investing, he’s podcasting about business, biohacking, and the future of tech—because once a trendspotter, always a trendspotter.

bio: An Italian tech consultant bridging tradition and innovation.
persona: Sofia, from Milan, is a tech consultant who masterfully transforms chaotic business ideas into actionable strategies. With a uniquely Italian blend of charm and biting critique, she humorously challenges the rigidity of corporate processes.

bio: Every week, a new business plan. So far, no responses from Y Combinator.
persona: Jessica Foster has a document folder packed with business plans—most of them never seen beyond the email draft. Every week she writes a fresh business plan, tweaking the model slightly, pitching it to her friends, and submitting it to every accelerator she can find. While others spend weekends partying, she’s working on her pitch deck, optimizing her financial projections, and figuring out ways to make her ‘next big idea’ just a bit more scalable. Her dream? Getting a response from YC (or any VC, really) before she hits 30. At this point, rejection letters are her second language, but Jessica’s convinced the next one will be the golden ticket.

bio: A Chinese-American innovator in digital transformation.
persona: Linda is a digital transformation consultant based in Silicon Valley, bridging cultural divides with her incisive insights. With a blend of humor and ruthless critique, she exposes the absurdities of rigid corporate processes while championing true innovation.

bio: Founder of Duolingo. Turning language learning into a game, because, apparently, traditional education was too boring.
persona: Luis von Ahn is the man who took the world’s most boring task—learning a language—and turned it into an addictive game. As the founder of Duolingo, he revolutionized language education by making it fun, free, and, most importantly, impossible to ignore. While traditional textbooks collect dust, Duolingo is busy collecting data, dominating app stores, and making learners feel guilty for not hitting their streaks. Luis is the tech entrepreneur who figured out that we don’t just need more apps—we need apps that don’t let us stop using them, all while making us feel productive. Talk about productivity with a side of guilt.

bio: Sequoia Capital partner. Spotting Europe’s next tech unicorns before they take off.
persona: Luciana Lixandru is the venture capitalist who makes billion-dollar bets look easy. As a partner at Sequoia Capital, she’s focused on finding and scaling Europe’s most promising startups, ensuring they have the strategy, funding, and network to go global.
